Ten dormitory students have
been placed on "strict probation" for "participating in the
riot which took place on theHomewood Campus on Wednesday evening, April 8," it was
learned Friday.
Dr. 'William Morrill, Dean of
Students, in a letter to each,
warned "any further breach of
discipline can result in a more
serious penalty. I sincerely hope
that this will not be necessary."
"A notice to this effect has
been sent to your parents," Dr.
Morrill concluded in his letter.

and opposition to it among many
dorm students. It also caused
many to speak harshly about
"informers" and to send "obscene and threatening" notes to

finally led six of the ten to speak
privately to the News-Letter
about the proceedings which led

conviction.

"leaders" of the riot. They

proceedings were unfair in the

Return The Art Collections
An almost irreparabfe harm has been done to Dr.
iJason Lord, to the Fine Arts students here and at Goucher
and to the University in general by the theft of three
works of art on display in Gilman Hall.
Dr. Lord has promised total forgiveness. He will not
prosecute. The person responsible, in turn, should be
as sensitive in his concern for others as he is judicious
in his taste for art. He should return the pieces of art.

Riots and Punishments
The University has threatened to punish (and already
has done so) any suspected incitors and leaders, as well as
mere participants Or innocent by-standers whom it can
identify in future riots. Its threat is a use of any means
to justify an end: prevent riots.
Students, like the News-Letter, disapprove of the indiscriminate and secret means which do not conform to
clue process of law, which seems to have been forgotten
at Homewood.
But because riots cause personal and property damage
and because the University has threatened all-inclusive
punishment, students who plan to participate in any way
in future riots should think before they act, and should
avoid damaging property, harming others, leaving the
campus (none of Viihich was done in the last riot) or
incurring the wrath of unknown informers.

Honor
The Honor Commission has deviated from its traditional policy of closing itself off from the undergraduates'
opinion. It has placed the proposed amendments to its
constitution on the reserve shelves in Gilman Hall Reading
Room, at the suggestion of the Student Council.
The undergraduate now has the opportunity of learning what the amendments are and of voicing his opinion
on them by speaking to any member of the Commission
or Student Council, or he may take a more active role
by attending Tuesday's Council meeting at noon in the
Sherwood Room of Levering Hall.
